n

pese
A pea.
n

peseta
A Spanish silver coin and money of account equal to about nineteen cents and divided into 100 centesimos.
n

peshito
The earliest Syriac version of the Old Testament translated from Hebrew; also the incomplete Syriac version of the New Testament.
n

pesky
Pestering; vexatious; troublesome. Used also as an intensive.
adj

peso
A Spanish dollar; also an Argentine Chilian Colombian etc. coin equal to from 75 cents to a dollar; also a pound weight.
n

pessary
An instrument or device to be introduced into and worn in the vagina to support the uterus or remedy a malposition.
n

pessimism
The opinion or doctrine that everything in nature is ordered for or tends to the worst or that the world is wholly evil; -- opposed to optimism; A disposition to take the least hopeful view of things.
n

pessimist
One who advocates the doctrine of pessimism; -- opposed to optimist; One who looks on the dark side of things; Of or pertaining to pessimism; characterized by pessimism; gloomy; foreboding.
n

pessimistical
Pessimistic.
adj

pessimize
To hold or advocate the doctrine of pessimism.
v

pessulus
A delicate bar of cartilage connecting the dorsal and ventral extremities of the first pair of bronchial cartilages in the syrinx of birds.
n

pest
A fatal epidemic disease; a pestilence; specif. the plague; Anything which resembles a pest; one who or that which is troublesome noxious mischievous or destructive; a nuisance.
n

pestalozzian
Belonging to or characteristic of a system of elementary education which combined manual training with other instruction advocated and practiced by Jean Henri Pestalozzi (1746-1827) a Swiss teacher.
adj

pestalozzianism
The system of education introduced by Pestalozzi.
n

pester
To trouble; to disturb; to annoy; to harass with petty vexations; To crowd together in an annoying way; to overcrowd; to infest.
v

pesterer
One who pesters or harasses.
n

pesterment
The act of pestering or the state of being pestered; vexation; worry.
n

pesterous
Inclined to pester. Also vexatious; encumbering; burdensome.
adj

pestful
Pestiferous.
adj

pesthouse
A house or hospital for persons who are infected with any pestilential disease.
n

pestiduct
That which conveys contagion or infection.
n

pestiferous
Pest-bearing; pestilential; noxious to health; malignant; infectious; contagious; as pestiferous bodies; Noxious to peace to morals or to society; vicious; hurtful; destructive; as a pestiferous demagogue.
adj

pestiferously
In a pestiferuos manner.
adv

pestilence
Specifically the disease known as the plague; hence any contagious or infectious epidemic disease that is virulent and devastating; Fig.: That which is pestilent noxious or pernicious to the moral character of great numbers.
n

pestilent
Pestilential; noxious; pernicious; mischievous.
adj

pestilential
Having the nature or qualities of a pestilence; Hence: Mischievous; noxious; pernicious; morally destructive.
adj

pestilentially
Pestilently.
adv

pestilentious
Pestilential.
adj

pestilently
In a pestilent manner; mischievously; destructively.
adv

pestilentness
The quality of being pestilent.
n

pestillation
The act of pounding and bruising with a pestle in a mortar.
n

pestle
An implement for pounding and breaking or braying substances in a mortar; as to grind with a mortar and pestle; A constable's or bailiff's staff; -- so called from its shape; The leg and leg bone of an animal especially of a pig; as a pestle of pork; To pound pulverize bray or mix with a pestle or as with a pestle; to use a pestle.
n

pesto
A sauce used in Italian cuisine typically made by blending olive oil basil garlic pine nuts and grated parmesan cheese; it is served hot or cold over pasta meat or fish. Where pine nuts are expensive sunflower seeds are sometimes substituted.
n

pet
A cade lamb; a lamb brought up by hand; Any person especially cherished and indulged; a fondling; a darling; often a favorite child; A slight fit of peevishness or fretfulness; Any animal kept as a companion usually in or around one's home typically domesticated and cared for attentively and often affectionately. Distinguished from animals raised for food or to perform useful tasks as a draft animal; Petted; indulged; admired; cherished; as a pet child; a pet lamb; a pet theory; a pet animal; To treat as a pet; to fondle; to indulge; as she was petted and spoiled; To be a pet.
n

petal
One of the leaves of the corolla or the colored leaves of a flower. See Corolla and Illust. of Flower; One of the expanded ambulacra which form a rosette on the black of certain Echini.
n

petaled
Having petals; as a petaled flower; -- opposed to apetalous and much used in compounds; as one-petaled three-petaled etc.
adj

petaliferous
Bearing petals.
adj

petaliform
Having the form of a petal; petaloid; petal-shaped.
adj

petaline
Pertaining to a petal; attached to or resembling a petal.
adj

petalism
A form of sentence among the ancient Syracusans by which they banished for five years a citizen suspected of having dangerous influence or ambition. It was similar to the ostracism in Athens; but olive leaves were used instead of shells for ballots.
n

petalite
A rare mineral occurring crystallized and in cleavable masses usually white or nearly so in color. It is a silicate of aluminia and lithia.
n

petalody
The metamorphosis of various floral organs usually stamens into petals.
n

petaloid
Petaline.
adj

petaloideous
Having the whole or part of the perianth petaline.
adj

petalosticha
An order of Echini including the irregular sea urchins as the spatangoids. See Spatangoid.
n

petalous
Having petals; petaled; -- opposed to apetalous.
adj

petalum
A petal.
n

petar
See Petard.
n

petard
A case containing powder to be exploded esp. a conical or cylindrical case of metal filled with powder and attached to a plank to be exploded against and break down gates barricades drawbridges etc. It has been superseded.
n

petardeer
One who managed a petard.
n

petasus
The winged cap of Mercury; also a broad-brimmed low-crowned hat worn by Greeks and Romans.
n

petaurist
Any flying marsupial of the genera Petaurus Phalangista Acrobata and allied genera. See Flying mouse under Flying and Phalangister.
n

petechiae
Small crimson purple or livid spots like flea-bites due to extravasation of blood which appear on the skin in malignant fevers etc.
n

petechial
Characterized by or pertaining to petechiae; spotted.
adj

peter
A common baptismal name for a man. The name of one of the apostles; To become exhausted; to run out; to fail; -- used generally with out; as that mine has petered out.
n

peterel
See Petrel.
n

peterero
See Pederero.
n

peterman
A fisherman; -- so called after the apostle Peter.
n

petersham
A rough knotted woolen cloth used chiefly for men's overcoats; also a coat of that material.
n

peterwort
See Saint Peter's-wort under Saint.
n

petiolar
Of or pertaining to petiole or proceeding from it; as a petiolar tendril; growing or supported upon a petiole; as a petiolar gland; a petiolar bud.
adj

petiolate
Having a stalk or petiole; as a petioleate leaf; the petiolated abdomen of certain Hymenoptera.
adj

petiole
A leafstalk; the footstalk of a leaf connecting the blade with the stem. See Illust. of Leaf; A stalk or peduncle.
n

petioled
Petiolate.
adj

petiolulate
Supported by its own petiolule.
adj

petiolule
A small petiole or the petiole of a leaflet.
n

petit
Small; little; insignificant; mean; -- Same as Petty.
adj

petite
Small little; of a woman or girl of small size and trim figure.
adj

petition
A prayer; a supplication; an imploration; an entreaty; especially a request of a solemn or formal kind; a prayer to the Supreme Being or to a person of superior power rank or authority; also a single clause in such a prayer; A formal written request addressed to an official person or to an organized body having power to grant it; specifically (Law) a supplication to government in either of its branches for the granting of a particular grace or right; -- in distinction from a memorial which calls certain facts to mind; also the written document; To make a prayer or request to; to ask from; to solicit; to entreat; especially to make a formal written supplication or application to as to any branch of the government; as to petition the court; to petition the governor; To make a petition or solicitation.
n

petitionarily
By way of begging the question; by an assumption.
adv

petitionary
Supplicatory; making a petition; Containing a petition; of the nature of a petition; as a petitionary epistle.
adj

petitionee
A person cited to answer or defend against a petition.
n

petitioner
One who presents a petition.
n

petitioning
The act of presenting apetition; a supplication.
n

petit-mal
The mildest form of epilepsy with momentary faintness or unconsciousness but without convulsions; -- opposed to grand mal.
misc

petitor
One who seeks or asks; a seeker; an applicant.
n

petitory
Petitioning; soliciting; supplicating.
adj

petong
See Packfong.
n

petralogy
See Petrology.
n

petrary
An ancient war engine for hurling stones.
n

petre
See Saltpeter.
n

petrean
Of or pertaining to rock.
adj

petrel
Any one of numerous species of longwinged sea birds belonging to the family Procellaridae. The small petrels or Mother Carey's chickens belong to Oceanites Oceanodroma Procellaria and several allied genera.
n

petrescence
The process of changing into stone; petrification.
n

petrescent
Petrifying; converting into stone; as petrescent water.
adj

petrifaction
The process of petrifying or changing into stone; conversion of any organic matter (animal or vegetable) into stone or a substance of stony hardness; The state or condition of being petrified; That which is petrified; popularly a body incrusted with stony matter; an incrustation; Fig.: Hardness; callousness; obduracy.
n

petrifactive
Having the quality of converting organic matter into stone; petrifying; Pertaining to or characterized by petrifaction.
adj

petrific
Petrifying; petrifactive.
adj

petrificate
To petrify.
v

petrification
See Petrifaction; Fig.: Obduracy; callousness.
n

petrify
To convert as any animal or vegetable matter into stone or stony substance; To make callous or obdurate; to stupefy; to paralyze; to transform; as by petrifaction; as to petrify the heart. Young; To become stone or of a stony hardness as organic matter by calcareous deposits; Fig.: To become stony callous or obdurate.
v

petrine
Of or pertaining to St. Peter; as the Petrine Epistles.
adj

petro-
A combining form from Gr. pe`tra a rock pe`tros a stone; as petrology petroglyphic.
misc

petrogale
Any Australian kangaroo of the genus Petrogale as the rock wallaby (Petrogale penicillata).
n

petroglyphic
Of or pertaining to petroglyphy.
adj

petroglyphy
The art or operation of carving figures or inscriptions on rock or stone.
n

petrographic
Pertaining to petrography.
adj

petrography
The art of writing on stone; The scientific description of rocks; that department of science which investigates the constitution of rocks; petrology.
n

petrohyoid
Pertaining to petrous oe periotic portion of the skull and the hyoid arch; as the petrohyoid muscles of the frog.
adj

petrol
Petroleum.
n

petrolatum
A semisolid unctuous substance neutral and without taste or odor derived from petroleum by distilling off the lighter portions and purifying the residue. It is a yellowish fatlike mass transparent in thin layers and somewhat fluorescent. It is used as a bland protective dressing and as a substitute for fatty materials in ointments.
n

petroleum
Rock oil mineral oil or natural oil a dark brown or greenish inflammable liquid which at certain points exists in the upper strata of the earth from whence it is pumped or forced by pressure of the gas attending it. It consists of a complex mixture of various hydrocarbons largely of the methane series but may vary much in appearance composition and properties. It is refined by distillation and the products include kerosene benzine gasoline paraffin etc.
n

petroleur
One who makes use of petroleum for incendiary purposes.
misc

petroline
A paraffin obtained from petroleum from Rangoon in India and practically identical with ordinary paraffin.
n

petrologic
Of or pertaining to petrology.
adj

petrologically
According to petrology.
adv

petrologist
One who is versed in petrology.
n

petrology
The department of science which is concerned with the mineralogical and chemical composition of rocks and with their classification: lithology; A treatise on petrology.
n

petromastoid
Of or pertaining to the petrous and mastoid parts of the temporal bone periotic.
adj

petromyzont
A lamprey.
n

petronel
A sort of hand cannon or portable firearm used in France in the 15th century.
n

petrosal
Hard; stony; petrous; as the petrosal bone; petrosal part of the temporal bone; A petrosal bone.
adj

petrosilex
Felsite.
n

petrosilicious
Containing or consisting of petrosilex.
adj

petrostearine
A solid unctuous material of which candles are made.
n

petrous
Like stone; hard; stony; rocky; as the petrous part of the temporal bone; Same as Petrosal.
adj

pettichaps
See Pettychaps.
n

petticoat
A loose under-garment worn by women and covering the body below the waist.
n

pettifog
To do a petty business as a lawyer; also to do law business in a petty or tricky way; To advocate like a pettifogger; to argue trickily; as to pettifog a claim.
v

pettifogger
A lawyer who deals in petty cases; an attorney whose methods are mean and tricky; an inferior lawyer.
n

pettifoggery
The practice or arts of a pettifogger; disreputable tricks; quibbles.
n

pettifogging
Paltry; quibbling; mean; Pettifoggery.
adj

pettifogulize
To act as a pettifogger; to use contemptible tricks.
v

pettily
In a petty manner; frivolously.
adv

pettiness
The quality or state of being petty or paltry; littleness; meanness.
n

pettish
Fretful; peevish; moody; capricious; inclined to ill temper.
adj

pettitoes
The toes or feet of a pig -- often used as food; sometimes in contempt the human feet.
n

petto
The breast.
n

petty
Little; trifling; inconsiderable; also inferior; subordinate; as a petty fault; a petty prince.
adj

pettychaps
Any one of several species of small European singing birds of the subfamily Sylviinae as the willow warbler the chiff-chaff and the golden warbler (Sylvia hortensis).
n

pettywhin
The needle furze. See under Needle.
n

petulance
The quality or state of being petulant; temporary peevishness; pettishness; capricious ill humor.
n

petulant
Forward; pert; insolent; wanton; Capriciously fretful; characterized by ill-natured freakishness; irritable.
adj

petulantly
In a petulant manner.
adv

petulcity
Wantonness; friskiness.
n

petulcous
Wanton; frisky; lustful.
adj

petune
To spray (tobacco) with a liquid intended to produce flavor or aroma.
v

petunia
A genus of solanaceous herbs with funnelform or salver-shaped corollas. Two species are common in cultivation Petunia violacera with reddish purple flowers and Petunia nyctaginiflora with white flowers. There are also many hybrid forms with variegated corollas.
n

petunse
Powdered fledspar kaolin or quartz used in the manufacture of porcelain.
n

petworth-marble
A kind of shell marble occurring in the Wealden clay at Petworth in Sussex England; -- called also Sussex marble.
misc

petzite
A telluride of silver and gold related to hessite.
n

peucedanin
A tasteless white crystalline substance extracted from the roots of the sulphurwort (Peucedanum) masterwort (Imperatoria) and other related plants; -- called also imperatorin.
n

peucil
A liquid resembling camphene obtained by treating turpentine hydrochloride with lime.
n

pew
One of the compartments in a church which are separated by low partitions and have long seats upon which several persons may sit; -- sometimes called slip. Pews were originally made square but are now usually long and narrow; Any structure shaped like a church pew as a stall formerly used by money lenders etc; a box in theater; a pen; a sheepfold; To furnish with pews.
n

pewee
A common American tyrant flycatcher (Sayornis phoebe or Sayornis fuscus). Called also pewit and phoebe; The woodcock.
n

pewet
Same as Pewit.
n

pewfellow
One who occupies the same pew with another; An intimate associate; a companion.
n

pewit
The lapwing.
n

pewter
A hard tough but easily fusible alloy originally consisting of tin with a little lead but afterwards modified by the addition of copper antimony or bismuth; Utensils or vessels made of pewter as dishes porringers drinking vessels tankards pots.
n

pewterer
One whose occupation is to make utensils of pewter; a pewtersmith.
n

pewtery
Belonging to or resembling pewter; as a pewtery taste.
adj

pexity
Nap of cloth.
n

peyers-glands
Patches of lymphoid nodules in the walls of the small intestiness; agminated glands; -- called also Peyer's patches. In typhoid fever they become the seat of ulcers which are regarded as the characteristic organic lesion of that disease.
misc

peytrel
The breastplate of a horse's armor or harness. [Spelt also peitrel.] See Poitrel.
n

peziza
A genus of fungi embracing a great number of species some of which are remarkable for their regular cuplike form and deep colors.
n

pezizoid
Resembling a fungus of the genus Peziza; having a cuplike form.
adj

pfennig
A small copper coin of Germany. It is the hundredth part of a mark or about a quarter of a cent in United States currency.
n

phacellus
One of the filaments on the inner surface of the gastric cavity of certain jellyfishes.
n

phacochere
The wart hog.
n

phacoid
Resembling a lentil; lenticular.
adj

phacolite
A colorless variety of chabazite; the original was from Leipa in Bohemia.
n

phacops
A genus of trilobites found in the Silurian and Devonian formations. Phacops bufo is one of the most common species.
n

phaeacian
Of or pertaining to the Phaeacians a fabulous seafaring people fond of the feast the lyre and the dance mentioned by Homer.
adj

phaenogam
Any plant of the class Phaenogamia.
n

phaenogamia
The class of flowering plants including all which have true flowers with distinct floral organs; phanerogamia.
n

phaenogamian
Same as Phaenogamous.
adj

phaenogamous
Having true flowers with with distinct floral organs; flowering.
adj

phaenomenon
See Phenomenon.
n

phaeospore
A brownish zoospore characteristic of an order (Phaeosporeae) of dark green or olive-colored algae.
n

phaethon
The son of Helios (Phoebus) that is the son of light or of the sun. He is fabled to have obtained permission to drive the chariot of the sun in doing which his want of skill would have set the world on fire had he not been struck with a thunderbolt by Jupiter and hurled headlong into the river Po; A genus of oceanic birds including the tropic birds.
n

phaeton
A four-wheeled carriage (with or without a top) open or having no side pieces in front of the seat. It is drawn by one or two horses; See Phaethon; A handsome American butterfly (Euphydryas Phaeton syn. Melitaea Phaeton). The upper side of the wings is black with orange-red spots and marginal crescents and several rows of cream-colored spots; -- called also Baltimore.
n

phagedena
A canine appetite; bulimia.
n

phagedenic
Of like or pertaining to phagedena; used in the treatment of phagedena; as a phagedenic ulcer or medicine.
adj

phagedenous
Phagedenic.
adj

phagocyte
A leucocyte which plays a part in retrogressive processes by taking up (eating) in the form of fine granules the parts to be removed.
n

phainopepla
A small crested passerine bird (Phainopepla nitens) native of Mexico and the Southern United States. The adult male is of a uniform glossy blue-black; the female is brownish. Called also black flycatcher.
n

phakoscope
An instrument for studying the mechanism of accommodation.
n

phalaena
A linnaean genus which included the moths in general.
n

phalaenid
Any moth of the family Phalaenidae of which the cankerworms are examples; a geometrid.
n

phalangeal
Of or pertaining to the phalanges. See Phalanx 2.
adj

phalanger
Any marsupial belonging to Phalangista Cuscus Petaurus and other genera of the family Phalangistidae. They are arboreal and the species of Petaurus are furnished with lateral parachutes. See Flying phalanger under Flying.
n

phalanges
pl. of Phalanx.
n

phalangial
Phalangeal.
adj

phalangid
One of the Phalangoidea.
n

phalangious
Of or pertaining to Phalangoidea.
adj

phalangist
Any arboreal marsupial of the genus Phalangista. The vulpine phalangist (Phalangista vulpina) is the largest species the full grown male being about two and a half feet long. It has a large bushy tail.
n

phalangister
Same as Phalangist.
n

phalangite
A soldier belonging to a phalanx.
n

phalangoidea
A division of Arachnoidea including the daddy longlegs or harvestman (Phalangium) and many similar kinds. They have long slender many-jointed legs; usually a rounded segmented abdomen; and chelate jaws. They breathe by tracheae. Called also Phalangides Phalangidea Phalangiida and Opilionea.
n

phalanstere
A phalanstery.
n

phalansterian
Of or pertaining to phalansterianism; One who favors the system of phalansteries proposed by Fourier.
adj

phalansterism
A system of phalansteries proposed by Fourier; Fourierism.
n

phalanstery
An association or community organized on the plan of Fourier. See Fourierism; The dwelling house of a Fourierite community.
n

phalanx
A body of heavy-armed infantry formed in ranks and files close and deep. There were several different arrangements the phalanx varying in depth from four to twenty-five or more ranks of men; Any body of troops or men formed in close array or any combination of people distinguished for firmness and solidity of a union; A Fourierite community; a phalanstery; One of the digital bones of the hand or foot beyond the metacarpus or metatarsus; an internode; A group or bundle of stamens as in polyadelphous flowers.
n

phalarope
Any species of Phalaropus and allied genera of small wading birds (Grallae) having lobate toes. They are often seen far from land swimming in large flocks. Called also sea goose.
n

phallic
Of or pertaining to the phallus or to phallism.
adj

phallicism
See Phallism.
n

phallism
The worship of the generative principle in nature symbolized by the phallus.
n

phallus
The emblem of the generative power in nature carried in procession in the Bacchic orgies or worshiped in various ways; The penis or clitoris or the embryonic or primitive organ from which either may be derived; A genus of fungi which have a fetid and disgusting odor; the stinkhorn.
n

phanar
A quarter of Constantinople which after the Turkish conquest of the city became the chief Greek quarter; hence the Greek officials of Turkey or phanariots as a class.
n

phanariot
One of the Greeks of Constantinople who after the Turkish conquest became powerful in clerical and other offices under Turkish patronage.
misc

phane
See Fane.
n

phanerite
Evident; visible.
adj

phanerocarpae
Same as Acraspeda.
n

phanerocodonic
Having an umbrella-shaped or bell-shaped body with a wide open cavity beneath; -- said of certain jellyfishes.
adj

phanerocrystalline
Distinctly crystalline; -- used of rocks. Opposed to cryptocrystalline.
adj

phanerodactyla
Same as Saururae.
n

phanerogamia
That one of the two primary divisions of the vegetable kingdom which contains the phanerogamic or flowering plants.
n

phanerogamian
Phanerogamous.
adj

phanerogamic
Having visible flowers containing distinct stamens and pistils; -- said of plants.
adj

phaneroglossal
Having a conspicious tongue; -- said of certain reptiles and insects.
adj

phantascope
An optical instrument or toy resembling the phenakistoscope and illustrating the same principle; -- called also phantasmascope.
n

phantasm
An image formed by the mind and supposed to be real or material; a shadowy or airy appearance; sometimes an optical illusion; a phantom; a dream; A mental image or representation of a real object; a fancy; a notion.
n

phantasma
A phantasm.
n

phantasmagoria
An optical effect produced by a magic lantern. The figures are painted in transparent colors and all the rest of the glass is opaque black. The screen is between the spectators and the instrument and the figures are often made to appear as in motion or to merge into one another; The apparatus by which such an effect is produced; Fig.: A medley of figures; illusive images.
n

phantasmagorial
Of relating to or resembling phantasmagoria; phantasmagoric.
adj

phantasmagoric
Of or pertaining to phantasmagoria; phantasmagorial.
adj

phantasmagory
See Phantasmagoria.
n

phantasmal
Pertaining to of the nature of or resembling a phantasm; spectral; illusive.
adj

phantasmascope
See Phantascope.
n

phantasmatical
Phantasmal.
adj

phantasmatography
A description of celestial phenomena as rainbows etc.
n

phantastic
See Fantastic.
adj

phantasy
See Fantasy and Fancy.
n

phantom
That which has only an apparent existence; an apparition; a specter; a phantasm; a sprite; an airy spirit; an ideal image; Being or of the nature of a phantom.
n

phantomatic
Phantasmal.
adj

phantom-circuit
The equivalent of an additional circuit or wire in reality not existing obtained by certain arrangements of real circuits as in some multiplex telegraph systems.
misc

pharaoh
A title by which the sovereigns of ancient Egypt were designated; See Faro.
n

pharaon
See Pharaoh 2. - denoting a quantity consisting of one more than one; one plus one more; -- representing the number two as an Arabic numeral.
n

pharaonic
Of or pertaining to the Pharaohs or kings of ancient Egypt.
adj

phare
A beacon tower; a lighthouse; Hence a harbor.
n

pharisaic
Of or pertaining to the Pharisees; resembling the Pharisees; Addicted to external forms and ceremonies; making a show of religion without the spirit of it; ceremonial; formal; hypocritical; self-righteous.
adj

pharisaism
The notions doctrines and conduct of the Pharisees as a sect; Rigid observance of external forms of religion without genuine piety; hypocrisy in religion; a censorious self-righteous spirit in matters of morals or manners.
n

pharisean
Following the practice of Pharisees; Pharisaic.
adj

pharisee
One of a sect or party among the Jews noted for a strict and formal observance of rites and ceremonies and of the traditions of the elders and whose pretensions to superior sanctity led them to separate themselves from the other Jews.
n

phariseeism
See Pharisaism.
n

pharmaceutic
Of or pertaining to the knowledge or art of pharmacy or to the art of preparing medicines according to the rules or formulas of pharmacy; as pharmaceutical preparations.
adj

pharmaceutics
The science of preparing medicines.
n

pharmaceutist
One skilled in pharmacy; a druggist. See the Note under Apothecary.
n

pharmacist
One skilled in pharmacy; a pharmaceutist; a druggist.
n

pharmacodymanics
That branch of pharmacology which treats of the action and the effects of medicines in the body and also their distribution in various bodily tissues over time and their breakdown and excretion.
n

pharmacognosis
That branch of pharmacology which treats of unprepared medicines or simples; -- usually called pharmacognosy and also pharmacography and pharmacomathy.
n

pharmacognosy
Pharmacognosis; The study of the distribution of methods for finding and properties of medically useful agents in natural sources especially plants.
n

pharmacography
See Pharmacognosis.
n

pharmacolite
A hydrous arsenate of lime usually occurring in silky fibers of a white or grayish color.
n

pharmacologist
One skilled in pharmacology.
n

pharmacology
Knowledge of drugs or medicines; the art of preparing medicines; A treatise on the art of preparing medicines.
n

pharmacomathy
See Pharmacognosis.
n

pharmacon
A medicine or drug; also a poison.
n

pharmacopoeia
A book or treatise describing the drugs preparations etc. used in medicine; especially one that is issued by official authority and considered as an authoritative standard; A chemical laboratory.
n

pharmacopolist
One who sells medicines; an apothecary.
n

pharmacosiderite
A hydrous arsenate of iron occurring in green or yellowish green cubic crystals; cube ore.
n

pharmacy
The art or practice of preparing and preserving drugs and of compounding and dispensing medicines according to prescriptions of physicians; the occupation of an apothecary or a pharmaceutical chemist; A place where medicines are compounded; a drug store; an apothecary's shop.
n

pharo
A pharos; a lighthouse; See Faro.
n

pharology
The art or science which treats of lighthouses and signal lights.
n

pharos
A lighthouse or beacon for the guidance of seamen.
n

pharyngal
Pharyngeal.
adj

pharyngeal
Of or pertaining to the pharynx; in the region of the pharynx; A pharyngeal bone or cartilage; especially one of the lower pharyngeals which belong to the rudimentary fifth branchial arch in many fishes or one of the upper pharyngeals or pharyngobranchials which are the dorsal elements in the complete branchial arches.
adj

pharyngitis
Inflammation of the pharynx.
n

pharyngobranchial
Of or pertaining to the pharynx and the branchiae; -- applied especially to the dorsal elements in the branchial arches of fishes. See Pharyngeal.
adj

pharyngobranchii
Same as Leptocardia.
n

pharyngognathi
A division of fishes in which the lower pharyngeal bones are united. It includes the scaroid labroid and embioticoid fishes.
n

pharyngolaryngeal
Of or pertaining both to pharynx and the larynx.
adj

pharyngopneusta
A group of invertebrates including the Tunicata and Enteropneusta.
n

pharyngotome
An instrument for incising or scarifying the tonsils etc.
n

pharyngotomy
The operation of making an incision into the pharynx to remove a tumor or anything that obstructs the passage.
n

pharynx
The part of the alimentary canal between the cavity of the mouth and the esophagus. It has one or two external openings through the nose in the higher vertebrates and lateral branchial openings in fishes and some amphibias.
n

phascolome
A marsupial of the genus Phascolomys; a wombat.
n

phase
That which is exhibited to the eye; the appearance which anything manifests especially any one among different and varying appearances of the same object; Any appearance or aspect of an object of mental apprehension or view; as the problem has many phases; A particular appearance or state in a regularly recurring cycle of changes with respect to quantity of illumination or form of enlightened disk; as the phases of the moon or planets. See Illust. under Moon; Any one point or portion in a recurring series of changes as in the changes of motion of one of the particles constituting a wave or vibration; one portion of a series of such changes in distinction from a contrasted portion as the portion on one side of a position of equilibrium in contrast with that on the opposite side; A homogenous physically distinct portion of matter in a system not homogeneous; as the three phases ice water and aqueous vapor. A phase may be either a single chemical substance or a mixture as of gases; In certain birds and mammals one of two or more color variations characteristic of the species but independent of the ordinary seasonal and sexual differences and often also of age. Some of the herons which appear in white and colored phases and certain squirrels which are sometimes uniformly blackish instead of the usual coloration furnish examples. Color phases occur also in other animals notably in butterflies; The relation at any instant of a periodically varying electric magnitude as electro-motive force a current etc. to its initial value as expressed in factorial parts of the complete cycle. It is usually expressed in angular measure the cycle beb four right angles or 360�. Such periodic variations are generally well represented by sine curves; and phase relations are shown by the relative positions of the crests and hollows of such curves. Magnitudes which have the same phase are said to be in phase; the relation at any instant of any cyclically varying physical quantity such as voltage in an A.C. circuit an electromagnetic wave a sound wave or a rotating object to its initial value as expressed as a fractional part of the complete cycle. It is usually expressed in angular measure the complete cycle being 360�; To disturb the composure of; to disconcert; to nonplus; -- an older spelling now replaced by faze.
n

phase-angle
The angle expressing phase relation.
misc

phase-converter
A machine for converting an alternating current into an alternating current of a different number of phases and the same frequency.
misc

phase-displacement
A charge of phase whereby an alternating current attains its maximum later or earlier. An inductance would cause a lag a capacity would cause an advance in phase.
misc

phase-in
To begin an activity or to incorporate new elements or replace older elements of an activity in steps or by degrees.
v

phasel
The French bean or kidney bean.
n

phaseless
Without a phase or visible form.
adj

phase-meter
A device for measuring the difference in phase of two alternating currents of electromotive forces.
n

phaseolus
A genus of leguminous plants including the Lima bean the kidney bean the scarlet runner etc. See Bean.
n

phaseomannite
Same as Inosite.
n

phase-out
To halt (an activity) in steps or gradually; as to phase out use of 386-based PC's.
v

phase-rule
A generalization with regard to systems of chemical equilibrium discovered by Prof. J. Willard Gibbs. It may be stated thus: The degree of variableness (number of degrees of freedom) of a system is equal to the number of components minus the number of phases plus two. Thus if the components be salt and water and the phases salt ice saturated solution and vapor the system is invariant that is there is only one set of conditions under which these four phases can exist in equilibrium. If only three phases be considered the system is univariant that is the fixing of one condition as temperature determines the others.
misc

phase-splitter
A device by which a single-phase current is split into two or more currents differing in phase. It is used in starting single-phase induction motors.
misc

phase-splitting
The dephasing of the two parts of a single alternating current in two dissimilar branches of a given circuit.
misc

phasing
Pertaining to phase or differences of phase.
adj

phasing-current
The momentary current between two alternating-current generators when juxtaposed in parallel and not agreeing exactly in phase or period.
misc

phasing-transformer
Any of several transformers (there must be at least two) for changing phase.
misc

phasis
See Phase.
n

phasm
An apparition; a phantom; an appearance.
n

phasmid
Any orthopterous insect of the family Phasmidae as a leaf insect or a stick insect.
n

phassachate
The lead-colored agate; -- so called in reference to its color.
n

phatagin
The long-tailed pangolin (Manis tetradactyla); -- called also ipi.
n

pheasant
Any one of numerous species of large gallinaceous birds of the genus Phasianus and many other genera of the family Phasianidae found chiefly in Asia; The ruffed grouse.
n

pheasantry
A place for keeping and rearing pheasants.
n

phebe
See Phoebe.
n

pheer
See 1st Fere.
n

pheese
To comb; also to beat; to worry; Fretful excitement.
v

phelloderm
A layer of green parenchimatous cells formed on the inner side of the phellogen.
n

phellogen
The tissue of young cells which produces cork cells.
n

phelloplastics
Art of modeling in cork.
n

phenacetin
A white crystalline compound C10H13O2N once used in medicine principally as an antipyretic. It is now seldom used because of serious side effects.
n

phenacite
A glassy colorless mineral occurring in rhombohedral crystals sometimes used as a gem. It is a silicate of glucina and receives its name from its deceptive similarity to quartz.
n

phenakistoscope
A revolving disk on which figures drawn in different relative attitudes are seen successively so as to produce the appearance of an object in actual motion as an animal leaping etc. in consequence of the persistence of the successive visual impressions of the retina. It is often arranged so that the figures may be projected upon a screen.
n

phenalgin
An ammoniated compound of phenyl and acetamide used as an analgesic and antipyretic. It resembles phenacetin in its therapeutic action.
n

phenanthrene
A complex hydrocarbon C14H10 found in coal tar and obtained as a white crystalline substance with a bluish fluorescence.
n

phenanthridine
A nitrogenous hydrocarbon base C13H9N analogous to phenanthrene and quinoline.
n

phenanthroline
Either of two metameric nitrogenous hydrocarbon bases C12H8N2 analogous to phenanthridine but more highly nitrogenized.
n

phene
Benzene.
n

phenetol
The ethyl ether of phenol obtained as an aromatic liquid C6H5.O.C2H5.
n

phenic
Of pertaining to derived from or resembling phenyl or phenol.
adj

phenician
See Phoenician.
adj

phenicine
A purple powder precipitated when a sulphuric solution of indigo is diluted with water.
n

phenicious
Of a red color with a slight mixture of gray.
adj

phenicopter
A flamingo.
n

phenix
A bird fabled to exist single to be consumed by fire by its own act and to rise again from its ashes. Hence an emblem of immortality; A southern constellation; A marvelous person or thing.
n

phenocryst
One of the prominent embedded crystals of a porphyry.
n

phenogamia
Same as Phaenogamia.
n

phenogamian
Same as Phaenogamian Phaenogamic etc.
adj

phenol
A white or pinkish crystalline substance C6H5OH produced by the destructive distillation of many organic bodies as wood coal etc. and obtained from the heavy oil from coal tar; Any one of the series of hydroxyl derivatives of which phenol proper is the type.
n

phenolate
A compound of phenol analogous to a salt.
n

phenology
The science of the relations between climate and periodic biological phenomena as the migrations and breeding of birds the flowering and fruiting of plants etc.
n

phenolphthalein
A white or yellowish white crystalline substance C20H14O4 formed by condensation of the anhydride of phthalic acid and phenol. Its solution in alkalies is brilliant red but is decolorized by acids. This reaction being very delicate is used as an indicator. It is sometimes used as a laxative in veterinary medicine.
misc

phenomenal
Relating to or of the nature of a phenomenon; hence extraordinary; wonderful; as a phenomenal memory.
adj

phenomenalism
That theory which limits positive or scientific knowledge to phenomena only whether material or spiritual.
n

phenomenist
One who believes in the theory of phenomenalism.
n

phenomenology
A description history or explanation of phenomena.
n

phenomenon
An appearance; anything visible; whatever in matter or spirit is apparent to or is apprehended by observation; as the phenomena of heat light or electricity; phenomena of imagination or memory; That which strikes one as strange unusual or unaccountable; an extraordinary or very remarkable person thing or occurrence; as a musical phenomenon.
n

phenose
A sweet amorphous deliquescent substance obtained indirectly from benzene and isometric with and resembling dextrose.
n

phenyl
A hydrocarbon radical (C6H5) regarded as the essential residue of benzene and the basis of an immense number of aromatic derivatives.
n

phenylamine
Any one of certain class of organic bases regarded as formed from ammonia by the substitution of phenyl for hydrogen.
n

phenylene
A hypothetic radical (C6H4) occurring in certain derivatives of benzene; as phenylene diamine.
n

phenylic
Pertaining to derived from or containing phenyl.
adj

pheon
A bearing representing the head of a dart or javelin with long barbs which are engrailed on the inner edge.
n

phial
A glass vessel or bottle especially a small bottle for medicines; a vial; To put or keep in or as in a phial.
n

philabeg
See Filibeg.
n

philadelphian
Of or pertaining to Ptolemy Philadelphus or to one of the cities named Philadelphia esp. the modern city in Pennsylvania; A native or an inhabitant of Philadelphia; One of a society of mystics of the seventeenth century -- called also the Family of Love.
adj

philalethist
A lover of the truth.
n

philander
To make love to women; to play the male flirt; A lover; A South American opossum (Didelphys philander).
v

philanderer
One who hangs about women; a male flirt.
n

philanthrope
A philanthropist.

philanthropic

adj

philanthropinism
A system of education on so-called natural principles attempted in Germany in the last century by Basedow of Dessau.

philanthropinist
An advocate of or believer in philanthropinism.

philanthropist
One who practices philanthropy; one who loves mankind and seeks to promote the good of others.

philanthropistic
Pertaining to or characteristic of a philanthropist.
adj

philanthropy
Love to mankind; benevolence toward the whole human family; universal good will; desire and readiness to do good to all men; -- opposed to misanthropy.
n

philatelic

A kind of transparent reliquary with an ornamental top.

philauty

adj

philippic
Any one of the series of famous orations of Demosthenes the Grecian orator denouncing Philip king of Macedon; Hence: Any discourse or declamation abounding in acrimonious invective.
n

philippium
A rare and doubtful metallic element said to have been discovered in the mineral samarskite.
n

philippize
To support or advocate the cause of Philip of Macedon; To write or speak in the style of a philippic.
v

philister
A Philistine; -- a cant name given to townsmen by students in German universities.
n

philistine
A native or an inhabitant of ancient Philistia a coast region of southern Palestine; A bailiff; A person deficient in liberal culture and refinement; one without appreciation of the nobler aspirations and sentiments of humanity; one whose scope is limited to selfish and material interests; Of or pertaining to the Philistines; Uncultured; commonplace.
n

philistinism
The condition character aims and habits of the class called Philistines. See Philistine 3.
n

phillipsite
A hydrous silicate of aluminia lime and soda a zeolitic mineral commonly occurring in complex twin crystals often cruciform in shape; -- called also christianite.
n

phillygenin
A pearly crystalline substance obtained by the decomposition of phillyrin.
n

phillyrea
A genus of evergreen plants growing along the shores of the Mediterranean and breading a fruit resembling that of the olive.
n

phillyrin
A glucoside extracted from Phillyrea as a bitter white crystalline substance. It is sometimes used as a febrifuge.
n

philo-
A combining form from Gr. fi`los loving fond of attached to; as philosophy philotechnic.
misc

n

philomel
Same as Philomela the nightingale. - A small plain brown and gray European song bird (Luscinia megarhynchos syn. Luscinia luscinia). It sings at night and is celebrated for the sweetness of its song; A larger species (Lucinia philomela) of Eastern Europe having similar habits; the thrush nightingale. The name is also applied to other allied species.
n

philomela
The nightingale; philomel; A genus of birds including the nightingales.
n

philomene
The nightingale.
n

philomot

philomusical
Loving music. [R.]Busby.

n

philosophic
Of or pertaining to philosophy; versed in or imbued with the principles of philosophy; hence characterizing a philosopher; rational; wise; temperate; calm; cool.

philosophist

n

philosophy
Literally the love of inducing the search after wisdom; in actual usage the knowledge of phenomena as explained by and resolved into causes and reasons powers and laws; A particular philosophical system or theory; the hypothesis by which particular phenomena are explained; Practical wisdom; calmness of temper and judgment; equanimity; fortitude; stoicism; as to meet misfortune with philosophy; Reasoning; argumentation; The course of sciences read in the schools; A treatise on philosophy.
n

philostorgy
Natural affection as of parents for their children.
n

philotechnic

philter

n

phimosis
A condition of the penis in which the prepuce can not be drawn back so as to uncover the glans penis.
n

phitoness
Pythoness; witch.
n

phiz
The face or visage.
n

phlebitis
Inflammation of a vein.
n

phlebogram
A tracing (with the sphygmograph) of the movements of a vein or of the venous pulse.
n

phlebolite
A small calcareous concretion formed in a vein; a vein stone.
n

phlebology
A branch of anatomy which treats of the veins.
n

phlebotomist
One who practiced phlebotomy.
n

phlebotomize
To let blood from by opening a vein; to bleed.
v

phlebotomy
The act or practice of opening a vein for letting blood in the treatment of disease; venesection; bloodletting.
n

phlegethon
One of the principal rivers of Hades in the channel of which fire flowed instead of water.
n

phlegm
One of the four humors of which the ancients supposed the blood to be composed. See Humor; Viscid mucus secreted in abnormal quantity in the respiratory and digestive passages; A watery distilled liquor in distinction from a spirituous liquor; Sluggishness of temperament; dullness; want of interest; indifference; coldness.
n

phlegmagogue
A medicine supposed to expel phlegm.
n

phlegmasia
An inflammation; more particularly an inflammation of the internal organs.
n

phlegmatic
Watery; Abounding in phlegm; as phlegmatic humors; a phlegmatic constitution; Generating or causing phlegm; Not easily excited to action or passion; cold; dull; sluggish; heavy; as a phlegmatic person.
adj

phlegmatical
Phlegmatic.
adj

phlegmatically
In a phlegmatic manner.
adv

phlegmaticly
Phlegmatically.
adj

phlegmon
Purulent inflammation of the cellular or areolar tissue.
n

phlegmonous
Having the nature or properties of phlegmon; as phlegmonous pneumonia.
adj

phleme
See Fleam.
n

phleum
A genus of grasses including the timothy (Phleum pratense) which is highly valued for hay; cat's-tail grass.
n

phloem
That portion of fibrovascular bundles which corresponds to the inner bark; the liber tissue; -- distinguished from xylem.
n

phlogistian
A believer in the existence of phlogiston.
n

phlogistic
Of or pertaining to phlogiston or to belief in its existence; Inflammatory; belonging to inflammations and fevers.
adj

phlogistical
Phlogistic.
adj

phlogisticate
To combine phlogiston with; -- usually in the form and sense of the p. p. or the adj.; as highly phlogisticated substances.
v

phlogistication
The act or process of combining with phlogiston.
n

phlogiston
The hypothetical principle of fire or inflammability regarded by Stahl as a chemical element.
n

phlogogenous
Causing inflammation.
adj

phlogopite
A kind of mica having generally a peculiar bronze-red or copperlike color and a pearly luster. It is a silicate of aluminia with magnesia potash and some fluorine. It is characteristic of crystalline limestone or dolomite and serpentine. See Mica.
n

phlogosis
Inflammation of external parts of the body; erysipelatous inflammation.
n

phlogotic
Of or pertaining to phlogisis.
n

phloramine
A basic amido derivative of phloroglucin having an astringent taste.
n

phloretic
Pertaining to or derived from or designating an organic acid obtained by the decomposition of phloretin.
adj

phloretin
A bitter white crystalline substance obtained by the decomposition of phlorizin and formerly used to some extent as a substitute for quinine.
n

phlorizin
A bitter white crystalline glucoside extracted from the root bark of the apple pear cherry plum etc.
n

phloroglucin
A sweet white crystalline substance metameric with pyrogallol and obtained by the decomposition of phloretin and from certain gums as catechu kino etc. It belongs to the class of phenols. [Called also phloroglucinol.].
n

phlorol
A liquid metameric with xylenol belonging to the class of phenols and obtained by distilling certain salts of phloretic acid.
n

phlorone
A yellow crystalline substance having a peculiar unpleasant odor resembling the quinones and obtained from beechwood tar and coal tar as also by the oxidation of xylidine; -- called also xyloquinone.
n

phlox
A genus of American herbs having showy red white or purple flowers.
n

phlyctenular
Characterized by the presence of small pustules or whitish elevations resembling pustules; as phlyctenular ophthalmia.
adj

phoca
A genus of seals. It includes the common harbor seal and allied species. See Seal.
n

phocacean
Any species of Phoca; a seal.
n

phocal
Pertaining to seals.
adj

phocenic
Of or pertaining to dolphin oil or porpoise oil; -- said of an acid (called also delphinic acid) subsequently found to be identical with valeric acid.
adj

phocenin
See Delphin.
n

phocine
Of or pertaining to the seal tribe; phocal.
adj

phocodont
One of the Phocodontia.
n

phocodontia
A group of extinct carnivorous whales. Their teeth had compressed and serrated crowns. It includes Squalodon and allied genera.
n

phoebe
The pewee or pewit.
n

phoebus
Apollo; the sun god; The sun.

phoenician

adj

phoenicopterus
A genus of birds which includes the flamingoes.
n

phoenix
Same as Phenix; A genus of palms including the date tree.
n

pholad
Any species of Pholas.
n

pholadean
Pholad.
n

pholas
Any one of numerous species of marine bivalve mollusks of the genus Pholas or family Pholadidae. They bore holes for themselves in clay peat and soft rocks.
n

phonal
Of or relating to the voice; as phonal structure.
adj

phonascetics
Treatment for restoring or improving the voice.
n

phonation
The act or process by which articulate sounds are uttered; the utterance of articulate sounds; articulate speech.
n

phonautograph
An instrument by means of which a sound can be made to produce a visible trace or record of itself. It consists essentially of a resonant vessel usually of paraboloidal form closed at one end by a flexible membrane. A stylus attached to some point of the membrane records the movements of the latter as it vibrates upon a moving cylinder or plate.
n

phone
Colloq. for Telephone; a speech sound.
n_and_v

phoneidoscope
An instrument for studying the motions of sounding bodies by optical means. It consists of a tube across the end of which is stretched a film of soap solution thin enough to give colored bands the form and position of which are affected by sonorous vibrations.
n

phonetic
Of or pertaining to the voice or its use; Representing sounds; as phonetic characters; -- opposed to ideographic; as a phonetic notation.
adj

phonetically
In a phonetic manner.
adv

phonetician
One versed in phonetics; a phonetist.
n

phonetics
The doctrine or science of sounds; especially those of the human voice; phonology; The art of representing vocal sounds by signs and written characters.
n

phonetism
The science which treats of vocal sounds.
n

phonetist
One versed in phonetics; a phonologist; One who advocates a phonetic spelling.
n

phonetization
The act art or process of representing sounds by phonetic signs.
n

phonetize
To represent by phonetic signs.
v

phoney
imitating something superior; intended to deceive; fraudulent; having a misleading appearance; not genuine; counterfeit; fake; as a phoney diamond; a phoney hundred-dollar bill; pretending to be other than one is; putting on false appearances; insincere; hypocritical; -- of people; something or someone that is phony.
adj

phonic
Of or pertaining to sound; of the nature of sound; acoustic.
adj

phonics
same as Phonetics; a method of teaching reading and spelling to beginning students emphasizing the sound values of individual letters and syllables and the relationship between pronunciation and spelling. Contrasted to whole language method and sentence method.
n

phono
A South American butterfly (Ithonia phono) having nearly transparent wings.
n

phono-
A combining form from Gr. ? sound tone; as phonograph phonology.
misc

phonocamptic
Reflecting sound.
adj

phonogram
A letter character or mark used to represent a particular sound; A record of sounds made by a phonograph.
n

phonograph
A character or symbol used to represent a sound esp. one used in phonography; An instrument for the mechanical registration and reproduction of audible sounds as articulate speech etc. It consists of a rotating cylinder or disk covered with some material easily indented as tinfoil wax paraffin etc. above which is a thin plate carrying a stylus. As the plate vibrates under the influence of a sound the stylus makes minute indentations or undulations in the soft material and these when the cylinder or disk is again turned set the plate in vibration and reproduce the sound; an instrument for reproducing sounds especially music previously recorded on a plastic cylinder or disk as a pattern of bumps or wiggles in a groove. A needle (stylus) held in the groove is made to vibrate by motion (rotation) of the recording and the vibrations caused by the bumps and wiggles are transmitted directly to a membrane or first to an electronic amplifier circuit thereby reproducing with greater or less fidelity the original sounds. A phonograph which is equipped with electronics enabling the playback of sound with high fidelity to the original is often called a hi-fi.
n

phonographer
One versed or skilled in phonography; One who uses or is skilled in the use of the phonograph. See Phonograph 2.
n

phonographic
Of or pertaining to phonography; based upon phonography; Of or pertaining to phonograph; done by the phonograph.
adj

phonographically
In a phonographic manner; by means of phonograph.
adv

phonographist
Phonographer.
n

phonography
A description of the laws of the human voice or sounds uttered by the organs of speech; A representation of sounds by distinctive characters; commonly a system of shorthand writing invented by Isaac Pitman or a modification of his system much used by reporters; The art of constructing or using the phonograph.
n

phonolite
A compact feldspathic igneous rock containing nephelite hauynite etc. Thin slabs give a ringing sound when struck; -- called also clinkstone.
n

phonologer
A phonologist.
n

phonologic
Of or pertaining to phonology.
adj

phonologist
One versed in phonology.
n

phonology
The science or doctrine of the elementary sounds uttered by the human voice in speech including the various distinctions modifications and combinations of tones; phonetics. Also a treatise on sounds.
n

phonometer
An instrument for measuring sounds as to their intensity or the frequency of the vibrations.
n

phonomotor
An instrument in which motion is produced by the vibrations of a sounding body.
n

phonorganon
A speaking machine.
n

phonoscope
An instrument for observing or exhibiting the motions or properties of sounding bodies; especially an apparatus invented by Konig for testing the quality of musical strings.
n

phonotype
A type or character used in phonotypy.
n

phonotypic
Of or pertaining to phonotypy; as a phonotypic alphabet.
adj

phonotypist
One versed in phonotypy.
n

phonotypy
A method of phonetic printing of the English language as devised by Mr. Pitman in which nearly all the ordinary letters and many new forms are employed in order to indicate each elementary sound by a separate character.
n

phony
imitating something superior; intended to deceive; fraudulent; having a misleading appearance; not genuine; counterfeit; fake; as a phony diamond; a phony hundred-dollar bill; pretending to be other than one is; putting on false appearances; insincere; hypocritical; -- of people; something or someone that is phony.
adj

phorminx
A kind of lyre used by the Greeks.
n

phormium
A genus of liliaceous plants consisting of one species (Phormium tenax). See Flax-plant.
n

phorone
A yellow crystalline substance having a geraniumlike odor regarded as a complex derivative of acetone and obtained from certain camphor compounds.
n

phoronis
A remarkable genus of marine worms having tentacles around the mouth. It is usually classed with the gephyreans. Its larva (Actinotrocha) undergoes a peculiar metamorphosis.
n

phoronomia
See Phoronomics.
n

phoronomics
The science of motion; kinematics.
n

phosgene
Producing or produced by the action of light; -- used specifically to designate a gas also called carbonyl chloride. See Carbonyl; A reactive chemical substance (COCl2) also called carbonyl choride used in synthesis of numerous substances. In the First Worlds War it was also used as a poisonous gas in combat.
adj

phosgenite
A rare mineral occurring in tetragonal crystals of a white yellow or grayish color and adamantine luster. It is a chlorocarbonate of lead.
n

phospham
An inert amorphous white powder PN2H obtained by passing ammonia over heated phosphorus.
n

phosphate
A salt of phosphoric acid.
n

phosphatic
Pertaining to or containing phosphorus phosphoric acid or phosphates; as phosphatic nodules.
adj

phosphaturia
The excessive discharge of phosphates in the urine.
n

phosphene
A luminous impression produced through excitation of the retina by some cause other than the impingement upon it of rays of light as by pressure upon the eyeball when the lids are closed. Cf. After-image.
n

phosphide
A binary compound of phosphorus.
n

phosphine
A colorless gas PH3 analogous to ammonia and having a disagreeable odor resembling that of garlic. Called also hydrogen phosphide and formerly phosphureted hydrogen; Chrysaniline often in the form of a salt.
n

phosphinic
Pertaining to or designating certain acids analogous to the phosphonic acids but containing two hydrocarbon radicals and derived from the secondary phosphines by oxidation.
adj

phosphite
A salt of phosphorous acid.
n

phosphonic
Pertaining to or designating certain derivatives of phosphorous acid containing a hydrocarbon radical and analogous to the sulphonic acid.
adj

phosphonium
The hypothetical radical PH4 analogous to ammonium and regarded as the nucleus of certain derivatives of phosphine.
n

phosphor
Phosphorus; The planet Venus when appearing as the morning star; Lucifer.
n

phosphorate
To impregnate or combine with phosphorus or its compounds; as phosphorated oil.
v

phosphor-bronze
A variety of bronze possessing great hardness elasticity and toughness obtained by melting copper with tin phosphide. It contains one or two per cent of phosphorus and from five to fifteen per cent of tin.
n

phosphoreous
Phosphorescent.
adj

phosphoresce
To shine as phosphorus; to be phosphorescent; to emit a phosphoric light.
v

phosphorescence
The quality or state of being phosphorescent; or the act of phosphorescing; A phosphoric light.
n

phosphorescent
Shining with a phosphoric light; luminous without sensible heat.
adj

phosphoric
Of or pertaining to phosphorus; resembling or containing from us; specifically designating those compounds in which phosphorus has a higher valence as contrasted with the phosphorous compounds; Phosphorescent.
adj

phosphorical
Phosphoric.
adj

phosphorite
A massive variety of apatite.
n

phosphoritic
Pertaining to phosphorite; resembling or of the nature of phosphorite.
adj

phosphorize
To phosphorate.
v

phosphorized
Containing or impregnated with phosphorus.
adj

phosphorogenic
Generating phosphorescence; as phosphorogenic rays.
adj

phosphoroscope
An apparatus for observing the phosphorescence produced in different bodies by the action of light and for measuring its duration.
n

phosphorous
Of or pertaining to phosphorus; resembling or containing phosphorus; specifically designating those compounds in which phosphorus has a lower valence as contrasted with phosphoric compounds; as phosphorous acid H3PO3.
adj

phosphorus
The morning star; Phosphor; A poisonous nonmetallic element of the nitrogen group obtained as a white or yellowish translucent waxy substance having a characteristic disagreeable smell; this waxy allotropic form is also called yellow phosphorus to distinguish it from another allotropic form red phosphorus. It is very active chemically must be preserved under water and unites with oxygen even at ordinary temperatures giving a faint glow -- whence its name. It always occurs combined usually in phosphates as in the mineral apatite in bones etc. It is used in the composition on the tips of friction matches and for many other purposes. The molecule contains four atoms. Symbol P. Atomic weight 31.0; Hence any substance which shines in the dark like phosphorus as certain phosphorescent bodies.
n

phosphorus-steel
A steel in which the amount of phosphorus exceeds that of carbon.
misc

phosphoryl
The radical PO regarded as the typical nucleus of certain compounds.
n

phosphuret
A phosphide.
n

phosphureted
Impregnated or combined with phosphorus.
adj

photic
Of or pert. to light; specif. relating to the production of light by the lower animals.
adj

photic-region
The uppermost zone of the sea which receives the most light.
misc

photics
The science of light; -- a general term sometimes employed when optics is restricted to light as a producing vision.
n

photism
A luminous image or appearance of a hallucinatory character.
n

photo
A contraction of Photograph.
n

photo-
A combining form from Gr. fw^s fwto`s light; as photography phototype photometer.
misc

photobacterium
A genus including certain comma-shaped marine bacteria which emit bluish or greenish phosphorescence. Also any microorganism of this group.
n

photobiotic
Requiring light to live; incapable of living without light; as photobiotic plant cells.
adj

photoceramics
Art or process of decorating pottery with photographically prepared designs.
n

photochemical
Of or pertaining to chemical action of light or produced by it; as the photochemical changes of the visual purple of the retina.
adj

photochemistry
The branch of chemistry which relates to the effect of light in producing chemical changes as in photography.
n

photochromic
Of or pertaining to photochromy; produced by photochromy.
adj

photochromography
Art or process of printing colored photographs.
n

photochromoscope
A device for giving shifting effects of color to a photograph. The unmounted print made translucent is illuminated from behind with colored light; A combination of three optical lanterns for projecting objects on a screen in the colors of nature. The images of three partial photographs taken through color screens (red green and blue respectively) are superimposed. Each image is given its own primary color and these colors blend and reproduce the colors of the object.
n

photochromotype
A colored print made photomechanically; To represent by a colored print made by any photomechanical process.
n

photochromotypy
The art of making photochromotypes.
n

photochromy
The art or process of reproducing colors by photography.
n

photochronograph
An instrument for recording minute intervals of time. The record is made by the power of a magnetic field due to an electric signaling current to turn the plane of polarization of light. A flash coinciding in time and duration with the signal is thus produced and is photographed on a moving plate; An instrument for the photographic recording of star transits.
n

photochronography
Art of recording or measuring intervals of time by the photochronograph.
n

photodrome
An apparatus consisting of a large wheel with spokes which when turning very rapidly is illuminated by momentary flashes of light passing through slits in a rotating disk. By properly timing the succession of flashes the wheel is made to appear to be motionless or to rotate more or less slowly in either direction.
n

photodynamics
The relation of light to the movements of plants and their organs; the study of the phenomena of curvatures induced by the stimulus of light.
n

photo-electric
Acting by the operation of both light and electricity; -- said of apparatus for producing pictures by electric light; Pert. to or capable of developing photo-electricity.
adj

photo-electric-cell
A cell (as one of two electrodes embedded in selenium) which by exposure to light generates an electric current.
misc

photo-electricity
Electricity produced by light.
n

photo-electrograph
An electrometer registering by photography.
n

photo-electrotype
An electrotype plate formed in a mold made by photographing on prepared gelatine etc.
n

photo-engrave
To engrave by a photomechanical process; to make a photo-engraving of.
v

photo-engraving
The process of obtaining an etched or engraved plate from the photographic image to be used in printing; also a picture produced by such a process.
n

photo-epinasty
A disproportionately rapid growth of the upper surface of dorsiventral organs such as leaves through the stimulus of exposure to light.
n

photo-etch
To engrave or make an engraving of by any photomechanical process involving etching of the plate.
v

photo-etching
A photo-engraving produced by any process involving the etching of the plate.
n

photogalvanography
The art or process of making photo-electrotypes.
n

photogen
A light hydrocarbon oil resembling kerosene. It is obtained by distilling coal paraffin etc. and is used as a lubricant illuminant etc.
n

photogene
A photograph; A more or less continued impression or image on the retina.
n

photogenic
Of or pertaining to photogeny; producing or generating light.
adj

photogeny
See Photography.
n

photoglyphic
Pertaining to the art of engraving by the action of light.
adj

photoglyphy
Photoglyphic engraving. See under Photoglyphic.
n

photoglyptic
Same as Photoglyphic.
adj

photogram
A photograph.
n

photogrammeter
A phototheodolite or a camera designed for use in photogrammetry.
n

photogrammetry
A method of surveying or map making by photography used also in determining the height and motions of clouds sea waves and the like.
n

photograph
A picture or likeness obtained by photography; To take a picture or likeness of by means of photography; as to photograph a view; to photograph a group; To practice photography; to take photographs.
n

photographer
One who practices or is skilled in photography.
n

photographic
Of or pertaining to photography; obtained by photography; used ib photography; as a photographic picture; a photographic camera.
adj

photographist
A photographer.
n

photographometer
An instrument for determining the sensibility of the plates employed in photographic processes to luminous rays.
n

photographone
A device consisting essentially of an electric arc and a camera by which a series of photographs of the variations of the arc due to sound waves are obtained for reproduction by means of a selenium cell and a telephone.
n

photography
The science which relates to the action of light on sensitive bodies in the production of pictures the fixation of images and the like; The art or process of producing pictures by this action of light.
n

photogravure
A photoengraving; also the process by which such a picture is produced.
n

photoheliograph
A modified kind of telescope adapted to taking photographs of the sun.
n

photoheliometer
A double-lens instrument for measuring slight variations of the sun's diameter by photography utilizing the common chord of two overlapping images.
n

photolithograph
A lithographic picture or copy from a stone prepared by the aid of photography; To produce (a picture a copy) by the process of photolithography.
n

photolithographer
One who practices or one who employs photolithography.
n

photolithographic
Of or pertaining to photolithography; produced by photolithography.
n

photolithography
The art or process of producing photolithographs.
n

photologic
Pertaining to photology or the doctrine of light.
adj

photologist
One who studies or expounds the laws of light.
n

photology
The doctrine or science of light explaining its nature and phenomena; optics.
n

photoluminescence
luminescence induced by exposure to light waves in the infrared to ultraviolet range.
adj

photoluminescent
Luminescent due to exposure to light waves.
adj

photomagnetic
Of or pertaining to photomagnetism.
adj

photomagnetism
The branch of science which treats of the relation of magnetism to light.
n

photomechanical
Pertaining to or designating any photographic process in which a printing surface is obtained without the intervention of hand engraving.
adj

photometer
An instrument for measuring the intensity of light or more especially for comparing the relative intensities of different lights or their relative illuminating power.
n

photometric
Of or pertaining to photometry or to a photometer.
adj

photometrician
One engaged in the scientific measurement of light; A specialist in photometry.
n

photometry
That branch of science which treats of the measurement of the intensity of light.
n

photomezzotype
A photomechanical process similar to collotype.
n

photomicrograph
An enlarged or macroscopic photograph of a microscopic object. See Microphotograph; A microscopically small photograph of an object.
n

photomicrography
The art of producing photomicrographs.
n

photonephograph
A nephoscope registering by photography commonly consisting of a pair of cameras used simultaneously.
n

photophilous
Light-loving; growing in strong light as many plants.
n

photophobia
A dread or intolerance of light.
n

photophone
An apparatus for the production of sound by the action of rays of light.
n

photophonic
Of or pertaining to photophone.
adj

photophony
The art or practice of using the photophone.
n

photophore
A form of endoscope using an electric light; A light-emitting organ; specif. one of the luminous spots on certain marine (mostly deep-sea) fishes.
n

photoplay
A play for representation or exhibition by moving pictures; also the moving-picture representation of a play.
n

photoprint
Any print made by a photomechanical process.
n

photopsia
An affection of the eye in which the patient perceives luminous rays flashes coruscations etc. See phosphene.
n

photopsy
Same as Photopsia.
n

photorelief
A printing surface in relief obtained by photographic means and subsequent manipulations.
n

photoscope
Anything employed for the observation of light or luminous effects.
n

photoscopic
Of or pertaining to the photoscope or its uses.
adj

photosculpture
A process in which by means of a number of photographs simultaneously taken from different points of view on the same level rough models of the figure or bust of a person or animal may be made with great expedition.
n

photosphere
A sphere of light; esp. the luminous envelope of the sun.
n

photospheric
Of or pertaining to the photosphere.
adj

photosynthesis
The process of constructive metabolism by which carbohydrates are formed from water vapor and the carbon dioxide of the air in the chlorophyll-containing tissues of plants exposed to the action of light. It was formerly called assimilation but this is now commonly used as in animal physiology. The details of the process are not yet clearly known. Baeyer's theory is that the carbon dioxide is reduced to carbon monoxide which uniting with the hydrogen of the water in the cell produces formaldehyde the latter forming various sugars through polymerization. Vines suggests that the carbohydrates are secretion products of the chloroplasts derived from decomposition of previously formed proteids. The food substances are usually quickly translocated those that accumulate being changed to starch which appears in the cells almost simultaneously with the sugars. The chloroplasts perform photosynthesis only in light and within a certain range of temperature varying according to climate. This is the only way in which a plant is able to organize carbohydrates. All plants without a chlorophyll apparatus as the fungi must be parasitic or saprophytic.
n

phototaxis
The influence of light on the movements of low organisms as various infusorians the zoospores of certain algae etc.; also the tendency to follow definite directions of motion or assume definite positions under such influence. If the migration is toward the source of light it is termed positive phototaxis; if away from the light negative phototaxis.
n

phototelegraphy
Telegraphy by means of light as by the heliograph or the photophone. Also less properly telephotography.
n

phototelescope
A telescope adapted for taking photographs of the heavenly bodies.
n

phototheodolite
An arrangement of two photographic cameras the plates of which may be brought into exactly the same plane used in surveying and map making. From the differences between two pictures taken at the same moment measurements in all dimensions of the region may be obtained.
n

phototherapy
The application of light for therapeutic purposes esp. for treating diseases of the skin.
n

photothermic
Of or pertaining to both light and heat.
adj

phototonus
A motile condition in plants resulting from exposure to light; An irritable condition of protoplasm resulting in movement due to a certain intensity of light.
n

phototopography
Photogrammetry.
n

phototrichromatic
Designating a photomechanical process for making reproductions in natural colors by three printings.
adj

phototropic
of or pertaining to phototropism; exhibiting phototropism; same as Heliotropic.
adj

phototropism
The tendency of growing plant organs to move or curve under the influence of light. In ordinary use the term is practically synonymous with heliotropism; exhibiting movement in a direction toward (positive phototropism) or away from (negative phototropism) a source of light.
n

phototype
A plate or block with a printing surface (usually in relief) obtained from a photograph; also any one of the many methods of processes by which such a printing surface is obtained.
n

phototypic
Of or pertaining to a phototype or phototypy.
adj

phototypography
Same as Phototypy.
n

phototypy
The art or process of producing phototypes.
n

photovisual
Of certain achromatic lenses having the same focus for the actinic and for the brightest of the visual rays.
adj

photoxylography
The process of producing a representation of an object on wood by photography for the use of the wood engraver.
n

photozincograph
A print made by photozincography.
n

photozincography
A process analogous to photolithography for reproducing photographed impressions transferred to zinc plate.
n

phragmocone
The thin chambered shell attached to the anterior end of a belemnite.
n

phragmosiphon
The siphon of a phragmocone.
n

phrasal
Of the nature of a phrase; consisting of a phrase; as a phrasal adverb.
adj

phrase
A brief expression sometimes a single word but usually two or more words forming an expression by themselves or being a portion of a sentence; as an adverbial phrase; A short pithy expression; especially one which is often employed; a peculiar or idiomatic turn of speech; as to err is human; A mode or form of speech; the manner or style in which any one expreses himself; diction; expression; A short clause or portion of a period; To express in words or in peculiar words; to call; to style; To use proper or fine phrases; To group notes into phrases; as he phrases well. See Phrase n. 4.
n

phraseless
Indescribable.
adj

phraseogram
A symbol for a phrase.
n

phraseologic
Of or pertaining to phraseology; consisting of a peculiar form of words.
adj

phraseologist
A collector or coiner of phrases.
n

phraseology
Manner of expression; peculiarity of diction; style; A collection of phrases; a phrase book.
n

phrasing
Method of expression; association of words; The act or method of grouping the notes so as to form distinct musical phrases.
n

phratry
A subdivision of a phyle or tribe in Athens.
n

phreatic
Subterranean; -- applied to sources supplying wells.
adj

phrenetic
Relating to phrenitis; suffering from frenzy; delirious; mad; frantic; frenetic; One who is phrenetic.
adj

phrenic
Of or pertaining to the diaphragm; diaphragmatic; as the phrenic nerve.
adj

phrenics
That branch of science which relates to the mind; mental philosophy.
n

phrenism
See Vital force under Vital.
n

phrenitis
Inflammation of the brain or of the meninges of the brain attended with acute fever and delirium; -- called also cephalitis; See Frenzy.
n

phrenograph
An instrument for registering the movements of the diaphragm or midriff in respiration.
n

phrenologer
A phrenologist.
n

phrenologic
Phrenological.
adj

phrenological
Of or pertaining to phrenology.
adj

phrenologist
One versed in phrenology; a craniologist.
n

phrenology
The science of the special functions of the several parts of the brain or of the supposed connection between the various faculties of the mind and particular organs in the brain; In popular usage the physiological hypothesis of Gall that the mental faculties and traits of character are shown on the surface of the head or skull; craniology.
n

phrenomagnetism
The power of exciting the organs of the brain by magnetic or mesmeric influence.
n

phrenosin
A nitrogenous body related to cerebrin supposed to exist in the brain.
n

phrensied
See Frenzied.
adj

phrensy
Violent and irrational excitement; delirium. See Frenzy; To render frantic.
n

phrentic
See Phrenetic.
adj

phryganeid
Any insect belonging to the Phryganeides.
n

phryganeides
A tribe of neuropterous insects which includes the caddice flies; -- called also Trichoptera. See Trichoptera.
n

phrygian
Of or pertaining to Phrygia or to its inhabitants; A native or inhabitant of Phrygia; A Montanist.
adj

phrygian-cap
A close-fitting cap represented in Greek art as worn by Orientals assumed to have been conical in shape. It has been adopted in modern art as the so-called liberty cap or cap of liberty.
misc

phthalate
A salt of phthalic acid.
n

phthalein
One of a series of artificial organic dyes made as condensation products of the phenols with phthalic acid and well represented by phenol phthalein. Their alkaline solutions are fluorescent.
n

phthalic
Pertaining to or designating a dibasic acid obtained by the oxidation of naphthalene and allied substances.
adj

phthalide
A lactone obtained by reduction of phthalyl chloride as a white crystalline substance; hence by extension any one of the series of which phthalide proper is the type.
n

phthalimide
An imido derivative of phthalic acid obtained as a white crystalline substance C6H4.(CO)2NH which has itself (like succinimide) acid properties and forms a series of salts. Cf. Imido acid under Imido.
n

phthalin
A colorless crystalline substance obtained by reduction from phthalein into which it is easily converted by oxidation; hence any one of the series of which phthalin proper is the type.
n

phthalyl
The hypothetical radical of phthalic acid.
n

phthiriasis
A disease (morbus pediculous) consisting in the excessive multiplication of lice on the human body.
n

phthisic
Same as Phthisis.
n

phthisical
Of or pertaining to phthisis; affected with phthisis; wasting; consumptive.
adj

phthisicky
Having phthisis or some symptom of it as difficulty in breathing.
adj

phthisiology
A treatise on phthisis.
n

phthisipneumonia
Pulmonary consumption.
n

phthisis
A wasting or consumption of the tissues. The term was formerly applied to many wasting diseases but is now usually restricted to pulmonary phthisis or consumption. See Consumption.
n

phthongal
Formed into or characterized by voice; vocalized; -- said of all the vowels and the semivowels also of the vocal or sonant consonants g d b l r v z etc; A vocalized element or letter.
adj

phthongometer
An instrument for measuring vocal sounds.
n

phthor
Fluorine.
n

phycite
See Erythrite 1. - used of a single unit or thing; not two or more; -- representing the number one as an Arabic numeral.
n

phycochrome
A bluish green coloring matter of certain algae.
n

phycocyanin
A blue coloring matter found in certain algae.
n

phycoerythrin
A red coloring matter found in algae of the subclass Florideae.
n

phycography
A description of seaweeds.
n

phycology
The science of algae or seaweeds; algology.
n

phycomater
A gelatin in which the algae spores have been supposed to vegetate.
n

phycomycetes
A large important class of parasitic or saprophytic fungi the algal or algalike fungi.
